Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Analgesia Regimens for Esophagectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adult patients scheduled for minimally invasive esophagectomy. The study was conducted in a tertiary care hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either EA or PVB.

Objective.evidence: To compare the effectiveness of EA and PVB in reducing postoperative pain and complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain measured by the Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the EA group and 100 to the PVB group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the EA group and 97 in the PVB group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean difference in NRS scores was 0.89 (95% CI: −0.47 to 2.24; p = 0.21).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included hypotension and urinary retention in the EA group (3%) and none in the PVB group.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
